timeline_html:
Here’s what I’m seeing: Your hair changes began about 4 months before this check-in (around May 2025). The main drivers are:

  • Chronic illness flare that began in Feb 2025 and is still ongoing — this keeps hair in a heightened stress cycle until the flare is managed.
  • Medication change from Mar–May 2025 — these shifts often trigger shedding 1–3 months later. Some of that effect has likely already tapered.
  • Major emotional stress (date not provided) — typically shows up 2–3 months later in shedding and may have added to the “waves” you noticed.

Why these matter: Illness flares and medication changes both disturb the growth phase, pushing more hairs to shed after a few months. Because your flare is still active, the body hasn’t fully calmed, which explains why the shedding feels cyclical.

Timeline forecast ⏳:
• Peak shedding likely landed May–Jul 2025.
• Medication-related fallout should settle by Sep–Nov 2025.
• The ongoing illness flare means stabilization won’t be complete until ~4–8 weeks after that flare is under control.
• Visible regrowth (baby hairs) usually follows 6–8 weeks after stabilization 🌱.

Where you are now: You’re sitting in the stabilization phase: the medication effect is winding down, but the chronic illness trigger is still keeping the cycle a bit unsettled. It makes sense you haven’t spotted new baby hairs yet.

❤️ You’re not alone. Once the flare eases, your body has a strong track record of growing new hair back — and that phase is ahead of you.
